clean_content:
Definition / general

* Well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor with poorly differentiated myosarcomatous component

Essential features

* Extremely rare lesion (two cases reported in English literature)* Lesion may transition from neuroendocrine to sarcomatous component or may have two discrete admixed components

Terminology

* Both reported cases use outdated term islet cell tumor, as they were published in 1989 and 2001

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [C25.4](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/C15-C26/C25-/C25.4) - malignant neoplasm of endocrine pancreas

Radiology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature01.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/1)

CT scan

Case reports

* 61 year old woman with 11 cm pancreas mass ([Mod Pathol 2001;14:1187](11706083))* Patient with widely metastatic lesion with rhabdomyosarcomatous component ([Am J Surg Pathol 1989;13:422](2540663))

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Lesion is primarily composed of typical well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor* Sarcomatous component may have rhabdomyosarcomatous features or may show spindled cells with enlarged nuclei arranged in bundles* Sarcomatous component is admixed with neuroendocrine component but transition may be gradual or abrupt (with sarcomatous component appearing as discrete nodules)

Microscopic (histologic) images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature02.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/2)

Nests of small, uniform polygonal cells

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature03.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/3)

Pushing margin

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature04.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/5)

Spindle cell component

  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature05.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/4)

Chromogranin

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature06.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/6)

Desmin

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature07.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/7)
â€ƒ
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/pancreaspensarcomatousNature08.jpg)](https://www.nature.com/articles/3880457/figures/8)

Topoisomerase II alpha

Positive stains

* Neuroendocrine markers ([synaptophysin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssynaptophysin.html), [chromogranin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainschromogranin.html)) in neuroendocrine component* [Desmin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsdesmin.html) in sarcomatous component

Electron microscopy description

* Z lines and thick filaments (if rhabdomyosarcomatous component)

Sample pathology report

* Pancreas and duodenum, Whipple procedure:
  + Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with focal sarcomatous differentiation (see synoptic report and comment)+ Comment: Sarcomatous differentiation is extremely rare in pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. Immunohistochemical stains for synaptophysin and chromogranin are positive in the typical neuroendocrine component and the Ki67 index in that component is approximately 2.7% (WHO grade 1).

Differential diagnosis

* [Leiomyosarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/softtissueleiomyosarcoma.html):
  + Most common sarcoma of pancreas+ Would not demonstrate neuroendocrine component
